facts.text: The appellant was appointed by the Local Self-Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order dated 27.11.1974 as Lady Doctor under Municipal Council, Ganganagar on temporary basis for six months or till RPSC candidate available.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed by the Local Self- Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order of appointment dated 27.11.1974, and posted as Lady Doctor under the Municipal Council, Ganganagar. There was a stipulation in the order of appointment that she was being posted purely on temporary basis for the period of six months or till the candidate selected by the Rajasthan Public Service Commission  hereinafter referred to as the Service Commission  is available, whichever is earlier.

facts.text: Appointment made under Section 308 of Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959 read with Rules 26 and 27 of Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment was made in exercise of powers companyferred under Section 308 of the Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959  in short the Act  read with Rules 26 and 27 of the Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963  in short the Rules .

facts.text: Appellant selected by Service Commission in October 1976 and August 1982 but did not join.

anchor.surface_text: Though the appellant was selected by the Service Commission in October 1976 and August 1982 she did number join pursuant to such selection and companytinued on the basis of the orders of extension issued by the Local Self-Government Department of the Government.

facts.text: Appellant's services terminated on 1.10.1988 on ground that Service Commission candidate available.

anchor.surface_text: On 1.10.1988 appellants services were terminated on the ground that the candidate selected by the Service Commission was available.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition number 3739 of 1988 before Rajasthan High Court challenging termination.

anchor.surface_text: Challenging such dismissal, appellant filed a writ petition bearing number 3739 of 1988 before the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court passed interim stay order on 12.10.1988 directing not to relieve appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Interim order of stay was passed on 12.10.1988 by the High Court with the direction that the appellant was number to be relieved from her post if she was number already relieved.

facts.text: Interim order made absolute by Rajasthan High Court on 21.3.1989.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the interim order was made absolute by order dated 21.3.1989.

facts.text: Single Judge of Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated 5.3.1993 held termination illegal and directed assessment of suitability and regularization.

anchor.surface_text: By judgment dated 5.3.1993, learned Single Judge held that termination of appellants services was illegal since order was passed ignoring of the fact that she had put in 14 years of service. The authorities were directed to adjudge her suitability within a period of one month and regularize her services with all benefits available to a substantively appointed member of the service.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan filed appeal to Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan filed appeal before the Division Bench of the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Division Bench by judgment dated 11.4.1997 held appellant continued as temporary employee, no right to post.

anchor.surface_text: But by the impugned judgment dated 11.4.1997, it was held by the Division Bench that the appellant companytinued merely as a temporary employee on the basis of appointment made under Rule 27 as she had number been selected by the Service Commission in accordance with the Rules. She had numberright to hold the post.

issues.text: whether the appellants termination from service is in order

anchor.surface_text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order.

issues.text: whether the long period of service rendered by the appellant has assumed permanency justifying regularization of her appointment

anchor.surface_text: Though her appointment initially was conditional, in view of the long period of service rendered by her, it had assumed permanency and learned Single Judge was justified directing regularization of appointment on a substantial basis.

issues.text: whether there is scope for regularization of the temporary appointment

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope of regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis. Considerable emphasis has been laid down by the appellant to the position that even for temporary appointment there was a selection.

issues.text: whether a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn from the extensions granted

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.
What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. The principle of legitimate expectation is still at a stage of evolution as pointed out in De Smith Administrative Law.

The authorities were directed to adjudge her suitability within a period of one month and regularize her services with all benefits available to a substantively appointed member of the service.

She had no right to hold the post.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appointment clearly temporary under Rules 26 and 27; no scope for regularization without regular selection by Commission.

arguments.claim: In view of long period of service (28 years), appointment assumed permanency; Single Judge justified in directing regularization; reliance on precedents like Director Institute of Management Development vs. Pushpa Srivastava etc.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that by now she had put in 28 years of service 14 years by the time the order of termination was passed and 14 years on the basis of interim directions given by the High Court and this Court. Though her appointment initially was conditional, in view of the long period of service rendered by her, it had assumed permanency and learned Single Judge was justified directing regularization of appointment on a substantial basis. The Division Bench overlooked the salient features and held that the temporary appointment originally made continued to hold field. Reliance was placed on Director, Institute of Management Development, U.P. vs. Pushpa Srivastava Smt. 1992 4 SCC 33, Ashwani Kumar Ors. vs. State of Bihar Ors. JT 1997 1 SC 243, Daily Rated Casual Labour Employed under PT Department through Bhartiya Dak Tar Mazdoor Manch vs. Union of India and Ors. 1988 1 SCC 122, Narender Chadha and Ors. vs. Union of India and Ors. 1986 2 SCC 157, State of Haryana and Anr. vs. Ram Diya 1990 2 SCR 431, State of U.P. and Ors. vs. Dr. Deep Narain Tripathi and Ors. 1996 8 SCC 454 to substantiate the plea. It was contended that in all these cases this Court took note of the long period of service rendered and the consequences and the benefits available to the concerned employee who had rendered such service without any blemish.

arguments.court_reasoning: No scope for regularization of irregular appointment; long service does not create right.

arguments.claim: Appointment under Rule 27: temporary/officiating; cannot continue beyond 1 year without Commission concurrence; terminated on refusal.

anchor.surface_text: Power of appointments is indicated in Rule Rule 27 deals with temporary or officiating appointments. It reads as follows Temporary or officiating appointments 1 A vacancy in the service may be temporarily filled by the Appointing Authority by appointing thereto in an officiating capacity an officer whose name is included in the list prepared under Rule 21 or in the lists under Rule 25 Provided that till the preparation of the first list or in case the list is exhausted, a vacant post may be filled by the Appointing Authority by appointing thereto a person eligible for appointment to the post by promotion or by appointing thereto temporarily a person eligible for appointment by direct recruitment to the service under the provision of these Rules Provided further that if all the officers in the grade or category from which appointment by promotion can be made under these rules, have already been promoted and no Officer is available from that grade or category the appointing authority may fill such vacancy by promotion from the grade or category next below such grade. No appointment made under sub-rule 1 shall be continued beyond a period of one year without referring it to the Commission for their concurrence and shall be terminated immediately on their refusal to concur.

arguments.claim: Initial appointment under Rules 26 and 27, temporary with condition if Commission candidate available.

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition that if candidate selected by the Service Commission is available, the employment was to come to end automatically.

arguments.claim: No scope for regularization unless appointment was regular; even temporary requires selection; no presumption of Commission concurrence from extensions.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Single Judge was swayed by the fact that for a longer period the concurrence was not sought for from the Commission and held that the inaction gave an undefeatable right to the appellant. The view was rightly set at naught by the Division Bench. The nature of employment and the authority with whose concurrence the continuation could be made are clearly spelt out in sub-rule 2 of Rule 27. There is no scope for taking a view that there is automatic extension once the period of one year is over in case reference was not made to the Commission. The appointment to the post of Lady Doctor in the Municipal Council is required to be made by selection through the medium of the Service Commission. That undisputedly has not been done. There is no scope of regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis. Considerable emphasis has been laid down by the appellant to the position that even for temporary appointment there was a selection. That is really of no consequence. Another plea of the appellant needs to be noticed. With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

arguments.claim: Precedents distinguished: no general rule for regularization based on long service; Article 142 directions case-specific.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellant were rendered in different factual background. A decision is an authority for what it decides and not for what could be inferred from the conclusion. Unless the initial recruitment is regularized through a prescribed agency, there is no scope for a demand for regularization. ... Article 142 power is confined only to this Court.

arguments.claim: Legitimate expectation does not apply: no representation, past practice or waiver; statutory rules override.

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. ... On the facts of the case delineated above, the principle of legitimate expectation has no application. It has not been shown as to how any act was done by the authorities which created an impression that the conditions attached in the original appointment order were waived. Mere continuance does not imply such waiver. No legitimate expectation can be founded on such unfounded impressions.

arguments.claim: Division Bench judgment correct; termination in order.

anchor.surface_text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order.

holdings.text: The appellant's termination from service is in order as she continued merely as a temporary employee under Rule 27 without selection by the Service Commission and had no right to hold the post.

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition that if candidate selected by the Service Commission is available, the employment was to come to end automatically. Sub-rule  2  of Rule 27 is of considerable importance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointment explicitly temporary under Rules 26/27; terminable upon availability of RPSC candidate; extensions do not alter nature without Commission concurrence; Division Bench correctly held no right to post.

holdings.text: Long period of service does not assume permanency or justify regularization of the temporary appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Single Judge was swayed by the fact that for a longer period the concurrence was not sought for from the Commission and held that the inaction gave an undefeatable right to the appellant. The view was rightly set at naught by the Division Bench. The nature of employment and the authority with whose concurrence the continuation could be made are clearly spelt out in sub-rule  2  of Rule 27.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary appointment under Rule 27 cannot be regularized without initial regular selection by Commission; long continuance does not create enforceable right; precedents distinguished as case-specific.

holdings.text: There is no scope for regularization unless the initial appointment was made on a regular basis through the Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment to the post of Lady Doctor in the Municipal Council is required to be made by selection through the medium of the Service Commission. That undisputedly has not been done. There is no scope of regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regularization requires prescribed agency (Commission) for initial recruitment; even temporary appointments need selection; ad-hoc cannot lead to substantive right.

holdings.text: No presumption of the Service Commission's concurrence can be drawn from the extensions granted, as currency of appointment lost after one year without reference.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the extension granted it was contended that a presumption of the Service Commissions concurrence can be drawn, when extensions were granted from time to time. This plea is without any substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 27(2) mandates reference to Commission after one year; no automatic extension; extensions operate only during effectiveness without implying concurrence.

holdings.text: The principle of legitimate expectation has no application on the facts of the case.

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. The principle of legitimate expectation is still at a stage of evolution as pointed out in De Smith Administrative Law  5th Edn. Para 8.038 . ... On the facts of the case delineated above, the principle of legitimate expectation has no application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation, past practice, or waiver shown to create expectation of permanency; mere continuance insufficient; clear statutory rules (Rule 27) override any expectation.

holdings.text: The Division Bench judgment is correct and requires no interference.

anchor.surface_text: The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of Rules 26/27, no regularization scope, no legitimate expectation, precedents distinguished; upholds termination.

anchor.surface_text: As the initial order of appointment dated 27.11.1974 shows appellant was appointed in terms of Rules 26 and 27. It was clearly indicated that the appointment was made on a temporary basis with further condition that if candidate selected by the Service Commission is available, the employment was to come to end automatically. Sub-rule  2  of Rule 27 is of considerable importance.
The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Single Judge was swayed by the fact that for a longer period the concurrence was not sought for from the Commission and held that the inaction gave an undefeatable right to the appellant. The view was rightly set at naught by the Division Bench. The nature of employment and the authority with whose concurrence the continuation could be made are clearly spelt out in sub-rule  2  of Rule 27.
The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment to the post of Lady Doctor in the Municipal Council is required to be made by selection through the medium of the Service Commission. That undisputedly has not been done. There is no scope of regularization unless the appointment was on regular basis.

anchor.surface_text: What remains to be considered is the plea of legitimate expectation. The principle of legitimate expectation is still at a stage of evolution as pointed out in De Smith Administrative Law  5th Edn. Para 8.038 . ... On the facts of the case delineated above, the principle of legitimate expectation has no application.
The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.
